Last night, I voted for the 2023 National Defense Authorization Act.
 
This bill supports our troops, invests in a 21st Century Arsenal of Democracy, and puts the U.S. on a better trajectory to out-compete the Chinese Communist Party.
https://t.co/iu5bw9aILL
By partnering with Japan and other like-minded allies, we can work to secure global supply chains, outcompete the Chinese Communist Party, and promote stability and security.

PM Kishida has ordered a doubling of Japan's defense budget to 2% of the country’s GDP in the next five years. 

The Japanese people are stepping up and responding to threats in their region in a truly meaningful way.

Prime Minister Kishida is delivering on his pledge to usher in a new, more proactive Japanese foreign policy, to the benefit of U.S. national security. 

No one-off decision, this is a direct consequence of the worsening security environment in Japan's own backyard.

I welcome the unveiling of Japan’s National Security Strategy and the real defense investments that will back it up.
 
Japan is a critical ally of the United States, particularly as we confront increasingly challenging security issues in the Indo-Pacific.

We owe it to our nation’s service members, military families, and veterans to pass this legislation repealing the 2002 AUMF and formalize the end of the Iraq War.

The current war authorities are outdated, unnecessary, and could be subject to misuse by future presidents.
 
Our bipartisan legislation will repeal the 1991 and 2002 AUMFs and reinstate Congress' constitutionally-mandated oversight role of declaring and ending wars.

On October 16, 2002, Congress voted to authorize the use of military force against the regime of Saddam Hussein.
 
As we mark the 20th anniversary, @TimKaine and I are calling for repeal of the 2002 AUMF, which the United States no longer requires.
 
https://t.co/6zkMPx34o2

.@OppInsights examined three areas of social capital in U.S. communities: Economic Connectedness, Cohesiveness, and Civic Engagement.

As we debate this next round of significant funding for Ukraine, I look forward to working with my colleagues to ensure the bill accomplishes precisely what Hoosiers expect.

Without audit requirements, reports to Congress, and diligent oversight, American tax dollars could be squandered. I also strongly support proposals to appoint a special inspector general to oversee U.S. assistance to Ukraine.

Our support to Ukraine must not be governed by emotions and blank checks, but must be tailored – in accordance with our own economic resources and appropriate guardrails to ensure the support is used effectively and accounted for.

We must support the Ukrainian people not only to repel Russia, but also to demonstrate our resolve that authoritarians – whether in Moscow, Beijing, Tehran, or elsewhere – will never be permitted to unilaterally redraw borders as they see fit.

Like all Hoosiers, I continue to be inspired by the heroic resistance of the Ukrainian people in the face of Russia’s invasion. 
 
While this war of aggression could end tomorrow if Putin decided to change course, tragically, he seems set on continuing this fight.

We should immediately impose the strongest possible economic sanctions to make Putin a global outcast. We must cut off Russia from SWIFT and freeze the life of luxury enjoyed by Putin and his oligarchs.

Our nation has an important tradition of placing civilian leaders in control of the Department of Defense. This is necessary to empower civilian voices within the military.
